   Acid:0.9 mmol/L, Albumin:3.1 g/dL, Ca++:8.6 mg/dL, Mg++:1.7 mg/dL,
   PO4:4.0 mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
   86 yo female with severe mitral regurgitation, severe tricuspid
   regurgitation, diastolic heart failure, atrial fibrillation transferred
   from [**Location (un) **] for evaluation of respiratory arrest.
   .
   # Altered Mental Status:  Unclear etiology, differential is broad
   including hypoxic or hypercarbic state, hypotension or secondary to
   sedative agents used for intubation earlier in the day, less likely.
   More concerning for acute central event given DC/CV with subsequent
   respiratory event.  Infectious process also on differential given
   recent pneumonia, but may be nosocomial infection given 6 day
   hospitalization.  Less likely causes include uremia, encephalopathy, or
   myxedema coma.  After discussion with pharmacy the half life of
   propofol in the elderly is markedly prolonged especially with prolonged
   infusions.  This may likely be the cause of her AMS, however will rule
   out other causes as well.
   - ABG on arrival
   - Full set of labs including lytes, LFTs, CBC, TSH, lactate
   - UA, UCx, Sputum, blood culture, c diff
   - Intubate for airway protection
   - Urine Tox screen
   - Likely will need Head CT/EEG once hemodynamically stable
   - Change sedation to fentanyl and versed
   .
   # Respiratory Failure:  Per report from [**Location (un) **], the patient's
   respiratory failure had resolved, however on arrival patient unable to
   protect airway with significant crackles bilaterally.  [**Month (only) 11**] have been
   initially secondary to episode of a fib with RVR in the setting of
   diastolic dysfunction and pneumonia with previous intubation from [**9-29**]
   until [**10-5**].
   - CXR on arrival
   - Antibiotic coverage for HAP - Vanc/Zosyn
   - Intubate on arrival for airway protection
   - Diuresis with IV lasix, will use lasix drip if pressures cannot
   tolerate boluses
   - Ventilator care
   - Nebs PRN
   .
   # Hypotension:  [**Month (only) 11**] have been secondary to A fib with RVR on arrival
   vs. infectious process.
   - DC/CV on arrival
   - Pressor support PRN - with levophed instead of dopamine given
   tachycardia
   - Antiobiotics as above
   - Follow up culture data
   .
   # CORONARIES:  History of quadruple CABG in [**2169**], has not been
   reevaluated since.  No evidence of acute ischemia.  No ASA given
   history of PUD.
   - Trend CE's
   - 12 lead EKG on arrival
   - Continue plavix and pravastatin
   - Hold metoprolol and lisinopril for now
   - If the patient is determined to be a candidate for MVR, will likely
   need coronary catheterization prior to consideration for valve
   replacement
   .
   # PUMP:  The patient has diastolic heart failure on most recent echo,
   but preserved systolic function.  Valvular disorders including severe
   mitral regurgitation and tricuspid regurgitation may be contributing to
   patient's dyspnea/respiratory arrest.  If the patient is truly
   symptomatic from mitral regurgitation, she would meet criteria for
   valve replacement.  If her symptoms are secondary to other causes, she
   may still meet criteria given severe nature, presence of pulmonary
   hypertension and possible new recurrence of atrial fibrillation.
   However, in the setting of recent altered mental status, hypotension,
   and respiratory failure will likely not pursue aggressive intervention
   at this time.
   - Repeat TTE in AM / Compare images to [**Location (un) **]
   - Consult CT [**Doctor First Name **] for possible valve replacement
   - Monitor I/Os and daily weights
   - Lasix PRN as above
   .
   # RHYTHM:  The patient has recent history of rapid A fib s/p DC/CV and
   amiodarone/digoxin loading with subsequent bradycardia and junctional
   rhythm.  On arrival, patient was in A fib with RVR and hypotensive.
   - DC/CV on arrival
   - Will hold AV nodal agents in the setting of recent junctional rhythm
   - Continue heparin drip for anticoagulation
   .
   # Hypothyroidism:  Check TSH.  Continue levothyroxine.
   .
   # Crohn's Disease:  No acute issues, continue to monitor.
   .
   # Macular Degeneration:  Continue brimonidine eye drops and
   PreserVision
   .
   # History of CVA:  Effected her right eye and is s/p left sided CEA.
   Continue plavix and pravastatin.  No aspirin secondary to PUD.
   .
   # PUD:  Continue home PPI
   .
   # Osteoporosis:  Continue actonel weekly
   .
   FEN:  Nutrition will need to be addressed in AM, will likely need tube
   feeds, unclear why the patient was maintained on TPN - consider speech
   and swallow as well as nutrition consult.
   .
   ACCESS: IJ placed at [**Location (un) **] on Left, Arterial line on right
   .
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with heparin gtt
   .
   CODE: Full Code
   .
   COMM:  Mr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 1139**] [**Known lastname 8715**]
   .
   DISPO: CCU for now
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   Multi Lumen - [**2189-10-6**] 05:52 PM
   Arterial Line - [**2189-10-6**] 07:00 PM
   22 Gauge - [**2189-10-6**] 09:55 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status:
   Disposition:

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 86-year-old female with severe mitral regurgitation, severe tricuspid regurgitation, diastolic heart failure, and atrial fibrillation. The patient was transferred to the ICU from another location for evaluation of respiratory arrest.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: T 37.2°C (99°F), HR 83 bpm, BP 125/50 mmHg, RR 21 breaths/min, SpO2 100%
* Respiratory support: Intubated and on mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 400 mL, PEEP of 5 cmH2O, and FiO2 of 40%
* Hemodynamic monitoring: Central venous catheter and arterial line in place
* Fluid balance: 911 mL of fluid has been infused over the past 24 hours, with a total balance of 11 mL
* Lab results: WBC 13.7, Hct 31.8, Plt 334, Cr 0.9, TropT 0.20, TCO2 29, Glucose 93

The patient has several potential medical complications that need to be monitored and managed:

* Altered mental status: The patient's mental status is unclear, with a differential diagnosis including hypoxic or hypercarbic state, hypotension, or sedative agents used for intubation. Further evaluation is needed to determine the cause of the altered mental status.
* Respiratory failure: The patient has severe respiratory failure, with bilateral crackles on auscultation. Further evaluation is needed to determine the cause of the respiratory failure.
* Hypotension: The patient's hypotension is likely secondary to atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response or an infectious process. Further evaluation is needed to determine the cause of the hypotension.
* Coronary artery disease: The patient has a history of quadruple coronary artery bypass grafting, but has not been reevaluated since. Further evaluation is needed to determine the current status of the patient's coronary arteries.
* Diastolic heart failure: The patient has diastolic heart failure on most recent echocardiogram, with preserved systolic function. Further evaluation is needed to determine the cause of the diastolic heart failure.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Antibiotic coverage for hospital-acquired pneumonia
* Intubation and mechanical ventilation for airway protection
* Pressor support for hypotension
* Antiplatelet therapy with plavix and pravastatin
* Monitor I/Os and daily weights
* Lasix PRN for diuresis
* Repeat TTE in the morning to compare images to those obtained at another location

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 86-year-old female who was transferred to the ICU from another location for evaluation of respiratory arrest. She has a history of severe mitral regurgitation, severe tricuspid regurgitation, diastolic heart failure, and atrial fibrillation.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Altered mental status: unclear etiology, but possible causes include hypoxic or hypercarbic state, hypotension, or sedative agents used for intubation.
* Respiratory failure: unable to protect airway with significant crackles bilaterally, and requires intubation and ventilator support.
* Hypotension: possible causes include atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, or infectious process.
* Coronaries: history of quadruple CABG, but no evidence of acute ischemia.
* Pump: diastolic heart failure with preserved systolic function, and valvular disorders may be contributing to patient's dyspnea/respiratory arrest.
* Rhythm: atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, and possible new recurrence of atrial fibrillation.
* Hypothyroidism: on levothyroxine therapy.
* Crohn's disease: no acute issues, but requires monitoring.
* Macular degeneration: on brimonidine eye drops and PreserVision.
* History of CVA: affected her right eye and is s/p left-sided CEA.
* PUD: on home PPI therapy.
* Osteoporosis: on actonel weekly.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

* Increased risk of respiratory failure due to inability to protect airway and significant crackles bilaterally.
* Increased risk of hypotension and cardiac arrest due to atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response and possible new recurrence of atrial fibrillation.
* Increased risk of infectious complications due to recent pneumonia and potential nosocomial infection.
* Increased risk of cardiac complications due to valvular disorders and diastolic heart failure.
* Increased risk of gastrointestinal bleeding due to PUD and potential use of anticoagulant therapy.
* Increased risk of osteoporotic fractures due to osteoporosis and potential use of anticoagulant therapy.

The patient requires close monitoring and management of her respiratory, cardiac, and metabolic status to prevent these potential complications.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following summary and potential medical complications are identified:

Summary:

The patient is an 86-year-old female who was transferred to the ICU from another location for evaluation of respiratory arrest. She has a history of severe mitral regurgitation, severe tricuspid regurgitation, diastolic heart failure, and atrial fibrillation. The patient's respiratory failure had resolved, but she is unable to protect her airway and requires intubation. She has also developed hypotension, which may be secondary to atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, infectious process, or hypovolemia. The patient's mental status is altered, and she has a history of stroke, hypothyroidism, Crohn's disease, macular degeneration, and osteoporosis.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen due to her underlying heart conditions, and she may require more aggressive interventions to improve her lung function.
2. Cardiac Complications: The patient's atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response may lead to cardiac complications, such as cardiogenic shock, cardiac tamponade, or ventricular fibrillation.
3. Infectious Process: The patient's sputum culture growing GNR may indicate an infectious process, which could worsen her respiratory failure and cardiac function.
4. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may be secondary to atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, infectious process, or hypovolemia, and may lead to organ dysfunction or failure.
5. Altered Mental Status: The patient's altered mental status may be due to oversedation, stroke, or infectious process, and may worsen her overall condition.
6. Clot Formation: The patient's atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response may increase her risk of clot formation, which could lead to stroke or other systemic embolic events.
7. Volume Overload: The patient's diastolic heart failure may lead to volume overload, which could worsen her cardiac function and respiratory failure.
8. Pneumonia: The patient's sputum culture growing GNR may indicate pneumonia, which could worsen her respiratory failure and cardiac function.
9. Ventilator-Associated Pneumonia (VAP): The patient's prolonged intubation may increase her risk of VAP, which could worsen her respiratory failure and cardiac function.
10. Cardiovascular Complications: The patient's history of quadruple CABG and recent atrial fibrillation may increase her risk of cardiovascular complications, such as cardiac tamponade, ventricular fibrillation, or cardiogenic shock.

Overall, the patient's complex medical condition requires close monitoring and management to prevent potential complications and improve her overall outcome.

   Assessment and Plan
   86 yo female with severe mitral regurgitation, severe tricuspid
   regurgitation, diastolic heart failure, atrial fibrillation transferred
   from [**Location (un) **] for evaluation of respiratory arrest.
   .
   # Altered Mental Status:  Unclear etiology, differential is broad
   including hypoxic or hypercarbic state, hypotension or secondary to
   sedative agents used for intubation earlier in the day, less likely.
   More concerning for acute central event given DC/CV with subsequent
   respiratory event.  Infectious process also on differential given
   recent pneumonia, but may be nosocomial infection given 6 day
   hospitalization.  Less likely causes include uremia, encephalopathy, or
   myxedema coma.  After discussion with pharmacy the half life of
   propofol in the elderly is markedly prolonged especially with prolonged
   infusions.  This may likely be the cause of her AMS, however will rule
   out other causes as well.
   - ABG on arrival
   - Full set of labs including lytes, LFTs, CBC, TSH, lactate
   - UA, UCx, Sputum, blood culture, c diff
   - Intubate for airway protection
   - Urine Tox screen
   - Likely will need Head CT/EEG once hemodynamically stable
   - Change sedation to fentanyl and versed
   - CT head to r/o CVA/ischemia
   .
   # Respiratory Failure:  Per report from [**Location (un) **], the patient's
   respiratory failure had resolved, however on arrival patient unable to
   protect airway with significant crackles bilaterally.  [**Month (only) 11**] have been
   initially secondary to episode of a fib with RVR in the setting of
   diastolic dysfunction and pneumonia with previous intubation from [**9-29**]
   until [**10-5**].
   - CXR on arrival
   - Antibiotic coverage for HAP - Vanc/Zosyn x7d; will f/u with ID re:
   need for Cefepime
   - Intubate on arrival for airway protection
   - Diuresis with IV lasix, will use lasix drip if pressures cannot
   tolerate boluses
   - Ventilator care
   - Nebs PRN
   - ABG later today
   .
   # Hypotension:  [**Month (only) 11**] have been secondary to A fib with RVR on arrival
   vs. infectious process.
   - DC/CV on arrival
   - Pressor support PRN - with levophed instead of dopamine given
   tachycardia
   - Antiobiotics as above
   - Follow up culture data
   - f/u CVP. SVO2
   - 1 unit PRBC for volume and to increase Hct
   .
   # CORONARIES:  History of quadruple CABG in [**2169**], has not been
   reevaluated since.  No evidence of acute ischemia.  No ASA given
   history of PUD.
   - Trend CE's
   - 12 lead EKG on arrival
   - Continue plavix and pravastatin
   - Hold metoprolol and lisinopril for now
   - If the patient is determined to be a candidate for MVR, will likely
   need coronary catheterization prior to consideration for valve
   replacement
   .
   # PUMP:  The patient has diastolic heart failure on most recent echo,
   but preserved systolic function.  Valvular disorders including severe
   mitral regurgitation and tricuspid regurgitation may be contributing to
   patient's dyspnea/respiratory arrest.  If the patient is truly
   symptomatic from mitral regurgitation, she would meet criteria for
   valve replacement.  If her symptoms are secondary to other causes, she
   may still meet criteria given severe nature, presence of pulmonary
   hypertension and possible new recurrence of atrial fibrillation.
   However, in the setting of recent altered mental status, hypotension,
   and respiratory failure will likely not pursue aggressive intervention
   at this time.
   - Repeat TEE in AM / Compare images to [**Location (un) **]
   - Consult CT [**Doctor First Name **] for possible valve replacement
   - Monitor I/Os and daily weights
   - Lasix PRN as above
   .
   # RHYTHM:  The patient has recent history of rapid A fib s/p DC/CV and
   amiodarone/digoxin loading with subsequent bradycardia and junctional
   rhythm.  On arrival, patient was in A fib with RVR and hypotensive.
   - DC/CV on arrival
   - Will hold AV nodal agents in the setting of recent junctional rhythm
   - Amiodarone po 200mg daily
   - Continue heparin drip for anticoagulation
   .
   # Cool LUE:  Will r/o clot given A fib with RVR, risk of clot vs.
   compartment syndrome.
   - Arterial study of RUE
   .
   # Hypothyroidism:  Check TSH.  Continue levothyroxine.
   .
   # Crohn's Disease:  No acute issues, continue to monitor.
   .
   # Macular Degeneration:  Continue brimonidine eye drops and
   PreserVision
   .
   # History of CVA:  Effected her right eye and is s/p left sided CEA.
   Continue plavix and pravastatin.  No aspirin secondary to PUD.
   .
   # PUD:  Continue home PPI
   .
   # Osteoporosis:  Continue actonel weekly
   .
   FEN:  Nutrition will need to be addressed in AM, will likely need tube
   feeds, unclear why the patient was maintained on TPN - consider speech
   and swallow as well as nutrition consult.
   .
   ACCESS: IJ placed at [**Location (un) **] on Left, Arterial line on right

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's current status as follows:

* The patient is a 86-year-old female with severe mitral regurgitation, severe tricuspid regurgitation, diastolic heart failure, and atrial fibrillation.
* She was transferred from another location for evaluation of respiratory arrest and is currently intubated for airway protection.
* The patient's altered mental status is unclear in etiology, but the differential includes hypoxic or hypercarbic state, hypotension, or secondary to sedative agents used for intubation.
* The patient has a history of quadruple CABG, but no evidence of acute ischemia.
* She has diastolic heart failure with preserved systolic function, and valvular disorders may be contributing to her symptoms.
* The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation, which was recently treated with DC/CV and amiodarone/digoxin loading.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient is currently intubated, and further deterioration of her respiratory status may occur.
* Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is 125/50 mmHg, which may be a concern, especially given her history of atrial fibrillation and diastolic heart failure.
* Altered mental status: The patient's altered mental status is unclear in etiology, and further evaluation is needed to determine the underlying cause.
* Infection: The patient has a history of pneumonia and is currently receiving antibiotics for suspected HAP.
* Thromboembolic events: The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation and is at risk for thromboembolic events, such as stroke or pulmonary embolism.
* Cardiovascular instability: The patient's heart failure and atrial fibrillation may lead to cardiovascular instability, including arrhythmias or cardiac arrest.
* Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's nutrition is currently unclear, and further evaluation is needed to determine her nutritional status and address any deficiencies.

I recommend the following:

* Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust her ventilator settings as needed.
* Continue to monitor her blood pressure and adjust her pressor support as needed.
* Further evaluate the patient's altered mental status, including a head CT and EEG, once she is hemodynamically stable.
* Continue to monitor the patient's infection status, including repeat cultures and sensitivities, and adjust her antibiotic therapy as needed.
* Consider consulting with a cardiologist to evaluate the patient's cardiac status and potential need for valve replacement.
* Monitor the patient's nutritional status and consider tube feeds or other nutritional support as needed.

 This is an 86 yr old pt w hx-CABG, severe MR/TR, pulm HTN,
   Afib(coumadin), CVA who was admitted  to OSH EW [**9-29**] with palpitations
   and weakness.
   She was found to be in rapid a-fib with RVR. She was cardioverted into
   NSR, but became bradycardic to the 30s and cyanotic and was intubated
   and started on dopamine. She was also started on IV amiodarone after
   bolus.
   -[**9-30**] she went into junctional rhythm and amiodarone was d/c.
   -[**10-4**] she was loaded with digoxin. [**10-5**] she went back into AF with
   rate in 70-90s and was tolerating it. She is presumed to have a
   community aquired PNA and is on levoquin.
   [**10-6**] AM-pt was extubated at -09:30  and was sating in low 90s on 35%
   ventimask. She was still somnulent, but rouseable and was following
   commands. She was on heparin at 250 units/hr, heparin at 5 mcg/kg and
   TPN at 42cc/hr. (It is unclear why she is receiving TPN and not tube
   feedings.) She is being transfered this afternoon [**10-6**] to be evaluated
   for valve replacement. She is full code.
   [**10-6**]-she arrived in CCU at 17:45 with SBP- in 80s, minimally
   responsive, intermittently gurgling. She was in A-fib with HR in 110
   to 130s with occasional PVCs. She was on heparin at 250 units/hr and
   5mcg/kg dopamine. Dopamine was increased and then changed to levophed.
   It was decided to intubate her and then cardiovert her. She was fully
   cultured. It was determined her BP readings were unreliable d/t hx left
   sc syndrome/obstruction and an ALINE was inserted in rt radial. Pt was
   switched from rocephin/levoquin to  Vanco/Zosyn and switched off
   initial sedation choice of propfol (had been on x 5 days at OSH) to
   versed/fentanyl, which were d/c by 12am d/t hypotension. Pt remains on
   low dose pressor, in SR, afebrile and somnolent off sedation currently.
   Family have been in to speak w CCU team and appear to understand
   current progress/plan of care.
   [**Date range (1) 8734**]- Pt to CT
 (-) for acute neuro change- thought to have
   somnolence d/t long term sedation/propofol. Pt increasingly alert since
   all sedation d/c 12am [**10-7**]. TEE postponed until [**10-8**] AM. Started on
   tube feeds- NPO after MN. Received 2 u PRBC for Hct 27-29. Remains on
   Levo/heparin gtt. New Rt IJ line inserted/ old TLC d/c.
   86 yo female with severe mitral regurgitation, severe tricuspid
   regurgitation, diastolic heart failure, atrial fibrillation transferred
   from [**Location (un) **] for evaluation of respiratory arrest.
   .
   # Altered Mental Status:  Suspect most likely to oversedation, however
   cannot r/o stroke, infectious process.  TSH and metabolic profile WNL.
   - ABG this afternoon
   - Full set of labs including lytes, LFTs, CBC, TSH, lactate
   - UA, UCx, Sputum, blood culture, c diff
   - Continue intubatation for airway protection until MS improves
   - Urine Tox screen pending
   - Hold sedation if tolerated.
   - CT head to r/o CVA/ischemia
   .
   # Respiratory Failure:  Per report from [**Location (un) **], the patient's
   respiratory failure had resolved, however on arrival patient unable to
   protect airway.  ABG with elevated PO2 this AM therefore FiO2
   decreased, CXR on arrival was not especially concerning for volume
   overload or pneumonia, however sputum growing GNR
   - CXR on arrival
   - Antibiotic coverage for HAP - Vanc/Zosyn (start date [**10-6**]) x7d; will
   f/u with ID re: need for Cefepime
   - Follow volume status and diuresis as indicated for volume overload,
   will aim to keep even today
   - Ventilator care
   - Nebs PRN
   - ABG later today
   .
   # Hypotension:  [**Month (only) 11**] have been secondary to A fib with RVR on arrival
   vs. infectious process.  Also concern for hypovolemia given recent
   diuresis and hypotension secondary to oversedation.
   - DC/CV on arrival
   - Pressor support PRN - with levophed instead of dopamine given
   tachycardia
   - Antiobiotics as above
   - Follow up culture data
   - f/u CVP. SVO2

   .
   # CORONARIES:  History of quadruple CABG in [**2169**], has not been
   reevaluated since.  No evidence of acute ischemia.  No ASA given
   history of PUD.
   - Trend CE's
   - 12 lead EKG on arrival
   - Continue plavix and pravastatin
   - Hold metoprolol and lisinopril for now
   - If the patient is determined to be a candidate for MVR, will likely
   need coronary catheterization prior to consideration for valve
   replacement
   .
   # PUMP:  The patient has diastolic heart failure on most recent echo,
   but preserved systolic function.  Valvular disorders including severe
   mitral regurgitation and tricuspid regurgitation may be contributing to
   patient's dyspnea/respiratory arrest.  If the patient is truly

Summary:

The patient is an 86-year-old female with a history of CABG, severe mitral regurgitation, severe tricuspid regurgitation, diastolic heart failure, atrial fibrillation, and CVA. She was admitted to the ICU with respiratory arrest, hypotension, and altered mental status. She was intubated and started on dopamine and heparin. She was later cardioverted into sinus rhythm and her sedation was discontinued. She remains on low-dose pressor support and is being monitored for respiratory failure, hypotension, and altered mental status.

Potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure had resolved initially, but she was unable to protect her airway on arrival. She is currently intubated and receiving ventilator care.
2. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension is secondary to atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, infectious process, and possible hypovolemia. She is receiving pressor support and antibiotics.
3. Altered mental status: The patient's altered mental status is suspected to be due to oversedation, but cannot be ruled out as a stroke or infectious process. She is being monitored for changes in mental status.
4. Infectious process: The patient has a history of pneumonia and is being treated with antibiotics for a possible community-acquired pneumonia.
5. Hypothyroidism: The patient has a history of hypothyroidism and is being treated with levothyroxine.
6. Crohn's disease: The patient has a history of Crohn's disease and is being monitored for any acute issues.
7. Macular degeneration: The patient has a history of macular degeneration and is being treated with brimonidine eye drops and PreserVision vitamin supplementation.
8. CVA: The patient has a history of CVA and is being treated with plavix and pravastatin.
9. PUD: The patient has a history of PUD and is being treated with a proton pump inhibitor.
10. Osteoporosis: The patient has a history of osteoporosis and is being treated with actonel weekly.

The patient's current medications include:

* Levothyroxine for hypothyroidism
* Plavix and pravastatin for CVA
* Proton pump inhibitor for PUD
* Actonel weekly for osteoporosis
* Omeprazole for stress ulcer prophylaxis
* Heparin for anticoagulation
* Dopamine and levophed for pressor support
* Amiodarone for atrial fibrillation
* Digoxin for atrial fibrillation
* Vancomycin and piperacillin/tazobactam for antibiotic coverage
* Fentanyl and versed for sedation

The patient's laboratory results include:

* Complete blood count (CBC) with normal white blood cell count and platelet count
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and creatinine (Cr) levels within normal limits
* Electrolyte levels within normal limits
* Blood glucose level within normal limits
* Troponin-T level within normal limits
* Lactic acid level within normal limits
* Albumin level within normal limits
* Calcium and magnesium levels within normal limits
* Phosphorus level within normal limits
* TSH level within normal limits

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 86-year-old female admitted to the ICU with severe mitral regurgitation, severe tricuspid regurgitation, diastolic heart failure, and atrial fibrillation. The patient's condition has been complicated by respiratory failure, hypotension, and altered mental status.

The patient's respiratory status is stable, with a respiratory rate of 25 breaths per minute and a SpO2 of 95%. The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation with a FiO2 of 30%. The patient's lung sounds are coarse bilaterally.

The patient's cardiac status is also stable, with a heart rate of 72 beats per minute and a blood pressure of 111/42 mmHg. The patient has a history of quadruple CABG and is taking Plavix and Pravastatin.

The patient's neurological status is concerning, with an altered mental status and a Glasgow Coma Scale score of 8. The patient's pupils are constricted and minimally reactive, and the patient is not tracking or following commands.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 13.7 x 10^9/L, a hemoglobin level of 10.2 g/dL, and a platelet count of 107 x 10^9/L. The patient's blood cultures are pending.

The patient's imaging studies show no acute hemorrhage, mass effect, or territorial vascular infarction on CT head, but there is a region of encephalomalacia within the right occipital lobe consistent with prior infarct.

The patient's medical plan includes continued antibiotic coverage for hospital-acquired pneumonia, ventilator care, and nebs as needed. The patient will also receive 250cc boluses as tolerated to manage hypotension and will be monitored for I/O and pressure response.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is stable, but the patient may continue to require mechanical ventilation.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient has a history of quadruple CABG and is taking anticoagulation medications. The patient may be at risk for bleeding or cardiac arrhythmias.
3. Neurological complications: The patient's altered mental status and constricted pupils are concerning and may indicate a neurological complication.
4. Infection: The patient's blood cultures are pending, and the patient may be at risk for infection.
5. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is low, and the patient may require further management to manage hypotension.
6. Fluid overload: The patient's fluid status is concerning, and the patient may be at risk for fluid overload.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 86-year-old female who was admitted to the ICU with severe mitral regurgitation, severe tricuspid regurgitation, diastolic heart failure, and atrial fibrillation. She was transferred from another location for evaluation of respiratory arrest.

Current Status:

* The patient's mental status is altered, and it is unclear whether this is due to oversedation, stroke, or an infectious process. A CT head was performed, which was negative for acute processes.
* The patient is intubated for airway protection due to respiratory failure, which has resolved. However, a CXR shows evidence of left lower lobe pneumonia.
* The patient has hypotension, which is suspected to be due to atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, hypovolemia, or oversedation.
* The patient has a history of coronary artery disease, quadruple CABG, and is taking Plavix and Pravastatin.
* The patient has diastolic heart failure with preserved systolic function, and valvular disorders may be contributing to her symptoms.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated, and there is a risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
2. Infectious process: The patient has a history of pneumonia, and the current CXR shows evidence of left lower lobe pneumonia. There is also a risk of sepsis due to the patient's altered mental status.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient has atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, which may lead to cardiac arrhythmias or cardiac arrest. There is also a risk of hypotension due to hypovolemia or oversedation.
4. Neurological complications: The patient has altered mental status, which may be due to oversedation, stroke, or an infectious process. There is also a risk of neurological deterioration due to the patient's underlying medical conditions.
5. Bleeding complications: The patient is taking anticoagulation therapy, which may increase the risk of bleeding complications.

Assessment and Plan:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust ventilator settings as needed.
2. Continue antibiotic coverage for pneumonia and monitor for signs of sepsis.
3. Monitor the patient's cardiac status and adjust medication as needed to control atrial fibrillation and hypotension.
4. Monitor the patient's neurological status and adjust sedation as needed to prevent oversedation.
5. Monitor the patient's bleeding risk and adjust anticoagulation therapy as needed.

Based on the patient's current status and potential medical complications, it is recommended to continue to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment as needed to prevent complications and improve outcomes.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 87-year-old woman who was transferred to the ICU for evaluation of severe mitral regurgitation and possible surgical repair. She has a history of quadruple CABG, atrial fibrillation, and diastolic heart failure. The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Altered mental status: The patient is responsive by opening her eyes, but does not track or follow commands. This could be due to oversedation, stroke, or infectious process.
* Respiratory failure: The patient has severe respiratory failure, which is being managed with mechanical ventilation. She has a history of aspiration pneumonia, and her chest X-ray shows evidence of left lower lobe pneumonia.
* Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure has been unstable, with episodes of hypotension. This could be due to hypovolemia, sepsis, or oversedation.
* Coronary arteries: The patient has a history of quadruple CABG, but there is no evidence of acute ischemia.
* Heart failure: The patient has diastolic heart failure, with preserved systolic function.
* Rhythm: The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation, which has resolved since DC cardioversion.

Potential medical complications that could arise include:

* Stroke or intracranial hemorrhage due to altered mental status
* Sepsis or septic shock due to pneumonia or other infectious process
* Cardiac arrhythmias or cardiac arrest due to hypotension or other cardiac conditions
* Respiratory failure or acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) due to pneumonia or other respiratory conditions
* Worsening of heart failure or cardiac function due to inadequate treatment or underlying cardiac disease
* Infection or sepsis due to indwelling lines or catheters
* Gastrointestinal bleeding or perforation due to anticoagulation therapy or other medications

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, C-reactive protein, and lactate levels, which may indicate an inflammatory response or sepsis. The patient's electrolyte levels are within normal limits, but her creatinine and blood urea nitrogen (BUN) levels are elevated, which may indicate kidney dysfunction.

The patient's imaging studies show evidence of encephalomalacia in the right occipital lobe, which may be due to prior stroke or other cerebral injury. The patient's chest X-ray shows evidence of left lower lobe pneumonia.

The patient's medical plan includes continuation of antibiotic therapy, management of respiratory failure, and optimization of cardiac function. The patient's family members have been informed of her condition and treatment plan, and they have been involved in her care.

Summary:

The patient is a 86-year-old female with a history of severe mitral regurgitation, severe tricuspid regurgitation, diastolic heart failure, and atrial fibrillation. She was transferred from another hospital for evaluation of respiratory arrest. She has been intubated and on mechanical ventilation. Her vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 37.6°C, heart rate of 111 bpm, and blood pressure of 90/50 mmHg. Her respiratory status is improving, but she remains on pressure support.

The patient has undergone several diagnostic tests, including an ultrasound and a transesophageal echocardiogram, which revealed moderate-severe mitral regurgitation, mild-moderate tricuspid regurgitation, and depressed left and right ventricular function. Her cardiac function is compromised, and she has a history of quadruple coronary artery bypass grafting.

The patient's mental status is altered, and she is not responding fully to commands. She has a history of Crohn's disease, macular degeneration, and osteoporosis, and is taking several medications, including plavix, pravastatin, and levothyroxine.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is improving, but she remains on mechanical ventilation. There is a risk of respiratory failure if she is not weaned off the ventilator successfully.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient has severe mitral regurgitation and tricuspid regurgitation, which can lead to cardiac failure and arrhythmias.
3. Infectious complications: The patient has a history of respiratory arrest and is at risk of developing pneumonia or other infections.
4. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is low, and there is a risk of hypovolemia or sepsis.
5. Altered mental status: The patient's mental status is altered, and there is a risk of worsening or developing further cognitive impairment.
6. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient has a history of Crohn's disease and is at risk of developing gastrointestinal complications, such as bleeding or perforation.
7. Ophthalmic complications: The patient has macular degeneration and is at risk of developing further vision loss.
8. Orthopedic complications: The patient has osteoporosis and is at risk of developing fractures or other orthopedic complications.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and wean her off the ventilator as tolerated.
2. Manage the patient's cardiac function with medications and consider valve replacement if necessary.
3. Monitor the patient's mental status and adjust her sedation and pain management as needed.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's gastrointestinal status and adjust her medication regimen as necessary.
5. Monitor the patient's ophthalmic status and adjust her treatment plan as necessary.
6. Monitor the patient's orthopedic status and adjust her treatment plan as necessary.
7. Consider consulting a cardiologist or other specialist for further management of the patient's cardiac condition.

Summary:

The patient is an 86-year-old female with severe mitral regurgitation, severe tricuspid regurgitation, diastolic heart failure, and atrial fibrillation. She was transferred from another hospital for evaluation of respiratory arrest. She is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure. Her laboratory results show elevated troponin-T and CK levels, indicating cardiac damage. She has a history of quadruple CABG, but no evidence of acute ischemia.

The patient's condition is complex and requires careful management. She has several potential medical complications that need to be addressed, including:

1. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure has been unstable, and she has required multiple boluses of fluids to maintain adequate blood pressure. She is also at risk for hypovolemia due to her recent diuresis.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure. She has a history of pneumonia and may require further antibiotic treatment.
3. Altered mental status: The patient's mental status has been altered due to oversedation, and she is at risk for further deterioration. She may require further evaluation, including an EEG, to rule out seizure activity.
4. Cardiac complications: The patient has severe mitral regurgitation and tricuspid regurgitation, which may be contributing to her respiratory failure. She may require further evaluation, including a cardiac catheterization, to determine the best course of treatment.
5. Infections: The patient has a history of pneumonia and may require further antibiotic treatment. She also has a central line and may be at risk for central line-associated bloodstream infection.
6. Thrombosis: The patient is at risk for thrombosis due to her cardiac condition and recent surgery. She may require anticoagulation therapy to prevent thrombotic complications.

Given the patient's complex medical condition, it is essential to carefully monitor her vital signs, laboratory results, and clinical status. She requires close collaboration between her healthcare providers, including cardiologists, pulmonologists, and intensivists, to ensure that her condition is properly managed and treated.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's condition as follows:

The patient is an 87-year-old female with a history of severe mitral regurgitation, atrial fibrillation, and quadruple CABG. She was transferred to the ICU for evaluation of respiratory arrest and severe mitral regurgitation. Her current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is on ventilator support with a pressure support of 15 cmH2O and a PEEP of 5 cmH2O. Her SpO2 is 95%, and her ABG shows a pH of 7.39, PaO2 of 403, and PaCO2 of 41.
* Cardiovascular: The patient has severe mitral regurgitation, mild aortic stenosis, and moderate to severe tricuspid regurgitation. Her LVEF is 40%, and her RV function is moderately depressed.
* Neurological: The patient has altered mental status, which is suspected to be due to oversedation, but cannot be ruled out as a stroke or infectious process.
* Renal: The patient has a creatinine level of 1.1 mg/dL and a blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level of 25 mg/dL.
* Hemodynamic: The patient has hypotension, which is being managed with fluid boluses and vasopressors.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is still on ventilator support, and there is a risk of developing respiratory failure if the ventilator settings are not optimized.
2. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's severe mitral regurgitation and tricuspid regurgitation can lead to heart failure, pulmonary hypertension, and arrhythmias.
3. Neurological complications: The patient's altered mental status can progress to coma or brain death if not addressed promptly.
4. Renal complications: The patient's creatinine level of 1.1 mg/dL and BUN level of 25 mg/dL indicate potential kidney damage, which can worsen if not managed properly.
5. Infection: The patient has a hospital-acquired pneumonia, and there is a risk of developing secondary infections, such as sepsis or endocarditis.

In light of these potential complications, I recommend the following:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust ventilator settings as needed.
2. Optimize the patient's cardiovascular status by managing her mitral and tricuspid regurgitation, and addressing any arrhythmias or heart failure.
3. Address the patient's neurological status by optimizing her sedation and pain management, and considering further diagnostic testing, such as a CT scan or EEG, if her mental status does not improve.
4. Monitor the patient's renal function closely and adjust her fluid management and medication regimen as needed.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's infection status and adjust her antibiotic regimen as needed.
6. Consider consulting a cardiothoracic surgeon to discuss the possibility of valve replacement or repair.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management to prevent potential complications and improve her outcome.

   volume overload or pneumonia, however sputum growing GNR, and CXR [**10-8**]
   shows evidence of LLL PNA. On pressure support now on ventilator.
   - Continue antibiotic coverage for HAP - Vanc/Zosyn (start date [**10-6**])
   x7d
   - Check vancomycin trough tomorrow morning
   - Confirm antibiotic dosing based upon renal function
   - Wean ventilator as tolerated and hopefully aim for extubation
   tomorrow, but more based on MS at this point rather than from a
   respiratory standpoint, although a combination of both components
   - Nebs
   - plan for chest PT s/p extubation
   - Lasix 40 IV now, goal -500cc today; as concern for volume overload
   given echo findings and significant fluid given during this
   hospitalization
   .
   # Hypotension:  [**Month (only) 11**] have been secondary to A fib with RVR on arrival
   vs. infectious process.  Also concern for hypovolemia given recent
   diuresis and hypotension secondary to oversedation.  In sinus rhythm
   since DC cardioversion [**10-7**]. Blood pressures significantly improved,
   even now on captopril.
   - Hold on pressors (with levophed instead of dopamine given
   tachycardia) unless evidence of end organ ischemia or hypotension which
   is unresponsive to fluids
   - Antiobiotics as above, especially with low-grade fever, concern for
   septic picture
   - Follow up culture data
   - Continues to ooze at RIJ site, so monitor BP and Hct; Hct stable
   overnight (was supratherapeutic on heparin, but was oozing even when
   not supratherapeutic earlier); put extra dressing or stitch as needed;
   request PICC line placement, so might be able to d/c RIJ if needed, but
   keep central access for now
   - Given higher blood pressure, uptitrate captopril to 25mg tid, as
   tolerated by BP
   .
   # CORONARIES:  History of quadruple CABG in [**2169**], has not been
   reevaluated since.  No evidence of acute ischemia.  No ASA given
   history of PUD.
   - Continue plavix and pravastatin
   - Hold metoprolol for now
   .
   # PUMP:  The patient has diastolic heart failure on most recent echo,
   but preserved systolic function.  Valvular disorders including severe
   mitral regurgitation and tricuspid regurgitation may be contributing to
   patient's dyspnea/respiratory arrest.  If the patient is truly
   symptomatic from mitral regurgitation, she would meet criteria for
   valve replacement.  If her symptoms are secondary to other causes, she
   may still meet criteria given severe nature, presence of pulmonary
   hypertension and possible new recurrence of atrial fibrillation.
   However, in the setting of recent altered mental status, hypotension,
   and respiratory failure will likely not pursue aggressive intervention
   at this time.  Feel patient volume-overloaded at this point, s/p
   multiple fluid boluses for hypotension
   - 40 IV lasix now; goal I/O = -500cc today
   - Monitor I/O
   - Consult CT [**Doctor First Name **] for possible valve replacement once pt stable
   - Uptitrate captopril to 25mg tid, as tolerated by BP
   - Continue to hold metoprolol
   .
   # RHYTHM:  The patient has recent history of rapid A fib s/p DC/CV and
   amiodarone/digoxin loading with subsequent bradycardia and junctional
   rhythm.  On arrival, patient was in A fib with RVR and hypotensive. In
   NSR since DC cardioversion.
   - Will hold AV nodal agents in the setting of recent junctional rhythm
   - Continue Amiodarone po 200mg daily
   - Continue heparin drip for anticoagulation (no coumadin, in case
   patient were to go for valvular surgery)
   .
   # Cool LUE:  Dopplers of LUE showed normal flow, warmth improved with
   heating pad and decreased discoloration.
   .
   # Hypothyroidism: TSH WNL, continue levothyroxine at home doses.
   .
   # Crohn's Disease:  No acute issues, continue to monitor.
   .
   # Macular Degeneration:  Continue brimonidine eye drops and
   PreserVision vitamin supplementation.
   .
   # History of CVA:  Affected her right eye and is s/p left sided CEA.
   Continue plavix and pravastatin.  No aspirin secondary to PUD.
   .
   # PUD:  Continue home PPI
   .
   # Osteoporosis:  Continue actonel weekly
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: Restart tube feeds, per nutrition rec
   Glycemic Control:  Monitor blood sugars, she has not been
   hyperglycemic.
   Lines:
   Arterial Line - [**2189-10-6**] 07:00 PM
   Multi Lumen - [**2189-10-7**] 04:16 PM (RIJ)
   Request PICC line placement today
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: heparin gtt, pneumoboots
   Stress ulcer: omeprazole
   VAP:  elevate HOB
   Comments: PT consult s/p extubation hopefully
   Communication:  Comments: with son [**Name (NI) 411**] ([**Telephone/Fax (1) 8721**]) and husband
   [**Name (NI) 1139**] ([**Telephone/Fax (1) 8722**]), both designated as HCP
   [**Name (NI) 129**] status: Full code

Summary:

The patient is an 86-year-old female with severe mitral regurgitation, severe tricuspid regurgitation, diastolic heart failure, and atrial fibrillation, who was transferred to the ICU for evaluation of respiratory arrest. She has been intubated and is currently on pressure support with a ventilator. Her mental status has improved, but she is still not fully responsive to commands. She has a low-grade fever, and her sputum culture is growing GNR. Her chest X-ray shows evidence of left lower lobe pneumonia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure has resolved, but she is still intubated and on pressure support. There is a risk of respiratory failure recurring, especially if her mental status does not improve.
2. Infectious process: The patient's sputum culture is growing GNR, and her chest X-ray shows evidence of pneumonia. There is a risk of sepsis or septic shock developing.
3. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure has been unstable, and she has required pressors to maintain adequate blood pressure. There is a risk of hypotension recurring, especially if her mental status does not improve.
4. Neurological depression: The patient's mental status has improved, but she is still not fully responsive to commands. There is a risk of neurological depression recurring, especially if her sedation is not properly managed.
5. Volume overload: The patient has received multiple fluid boluses for hypotension, and there is a risk of volume overload developing, especially if her diuresis is not adequate.
6. Cardiovascular instability: The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation and has required DC cardioversion. There is a risk of cardiovascular instability recurring, especially if her heart rate and rhythm are not properly managed.
7. Endocarditis: The patient has a history of quadruple CABG and has not been reevaluated since. There is a risk of endocarditis developing, especially if her valves are not properly treated.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust her ventilator settings as needed.
2. Continue to manage the patient's infection with antibiotics and monitor her sputum culture results.
3. Monitor the patient's blood pressure and adjust her pressors as needed to maintain adequate blood pressure.
4. Continue to manage the patient's sedation and monitor her mental status for signs of neurological depression.
5. Monitor the patient's diuresis and adjust her fluid management as needed to prevent volume overload.
6. Monitor the patient's cardiovascular status and adjust her heart rate and rhythm as needed to prevent cardiovascular instability.
7. Consider ordering a transesophageal echocardiogram to evaluate the patient's valves and assess for endocarditis.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's current condition as follows:

The patient is an 86-year-old female who was transferred to the ICU from another location for evaluation of respiratory arrest. She has a history of severe mitral regurgitation, severe tricuspid regurgitation, diastolic heart failure, and atrial fibrillation. The patient's current condition is characterized by:

1. Altered Mental Status: The patient is more alert and responsive, but still has not fully responded to commands. The cause of this altered mental status is unclear, but it is suspected to be due to oversedation, although stroke or infectious process cannot be ruled out.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient has been intubated for airway protection due to respiratory failure, which had resolved per report from the previous location. However, upon arrival, the patient was unable to protect her airway, and a chest X-ray showed evidence of left lower lobe pneumonia. The patient is currently on pressure support with the ventilator and is being weaned as tolerated.
3. Hypotension: The patient has had hypotension, which is suspected to be due to atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, hypovolemia, or infectious process. The patient's blood pressure is currently stable.
4. Cardiovascular: The patient has a history of quadruple CABG and has not been reevaluated since. There is no evidence of acute ischemia, and the patient is being continued on plavix and pravastatin.
5. Diastolic Heart Failure: The patient has diastolic heart failure, but preserved systolic function. Valvular disorders, including severe mitral regurgitation and tricuspid regurgitation, may be contributing to the patient's dyspnea and respiratory arrest.
6. Valvular Surgery: The patient may meet criteria for valve replacement, but it is unlikely to be pursued at this time due to the patient's current condition.
7. Hypothyroidism: The patient's thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) is within normal limits, and she is being continued on home doses of levothyroxine.
8. Other Medical Conditions: The patient has a history of Crohn's disease, macular degeneration, history of cerebrovascular accident (CVA), PUD, and osteoporosis, all of which are being managed accordingly.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status may worsen, and she may require further interventions such as non-invasive ventilation or extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO).
2. Infection: The patient's low-grade fever and positive sputum culture suggest the possibility of an infectious process, which may require further antibiotic therapy and monitoring.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient's atrial fibrillation and hypotension may worsen, and she may require further interventions such as cardioversion or vasopressor therapy.
4. Neurological complications: The patient's altered mental status may persist or worsen, and she may require further evaluation and management, including EEG or other neuroimaging studies.
5. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's diastolic heart failure may worsen, and she may require further interventions such as diuretic therapy or vasodilator therapy.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management of her respiratory, cardiovascular, and neurological status to prevent or mitigate potential complications.

Summary:

The patient is an 86-year-old female who was transferred to the ICU from another hospital for evaluation of respiratory arrest. She has a history of severe mitral regurgitation, severe tricuspid regurgitation, diastolic heart failure, and atrial fibrillation. She was found to have GNR in her sputum and a CXR showing evidence of LLL PNA. She was intubated due to respiratory failure and has been on pressure support ventilation. Her mental status has improved significantly, and she is now more alert and interactive.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Stroke: The patient's altered mental status could be due to a stroke, which is a concern given her history of atrial fibrillation and hypotension.
2. Critical Care Myopathy: The patient's muscle weakness could be due to critical care myopathy, which is a secondary thought given her recent hospitalization and fluid administration.
3. Infection: The patient's respiratory failure and sputum growing GNR suggest a possible infection, which could be contributing to her delirium.
4. Volume Overload: The patient's recent fluid administration and hypotension suggest a concern for volume overload, which could exacerbate her heart failure.
5. Hypothyroidism: The patient's recent TSH result was within normal limits, but she has a history of hypothyroidism and should continue to take her levothyroxine medication.
6. Crohn's Disease: The patient has a history of Crohn's disease and should continue to be monitored for any acute issues.
7. Macular Degeneration: The patient has a history of macular degeneration and should continue to take her brimonidine eye drops and PreserVision vitamin supplementation.
8. History of CVA: The patient has a history of CVA affecting her right eye and should continue to take her plavix and pravastatin medications.
9. PUD: The patient has a history of PUD and should continue to take her home PPI medication.
10. Osteoporosis: The patient has a history of osteoporosis and should continue to take her actonel medication weekly.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's mental status has improved significantly, and she is now more alert and interactive. She should continue to be monitored for any signs of infection or stroke. Her respiratory failure has resolved, and she should be evaluated for extubation today. Her hypotension has resolved, and she should continue to be monitored for any signs of volume overload. Her muscle weakness could be due to critical care myopathy, and she should be evaluated for this condition.

Summary:

The patient is an 86-year-old female with severe mitral regurgitation, severe tricuspid regurgitation, diastolic heart failure, and atrial fibrillation who was transferred to the ICU for evaluation of respiratory arrest. She has been experiencing altered mental status, hypotension, and respiratory failure. Her neurological exam shows general weakness, increased tone in the upper extremities, and areflexia in the knees and ankles, consistent with a diffuse weakness pattern. The patient's condition is complex, with multiple potential underlying causes, including oversedation, stroke, infectious process, and cardiac disease.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Neurological complications: The patient's altered mental status and diffuse weakness pattern suggest a potential neurological complication, such as a stroke, critical care myopathy, or encephalopathy.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen if not properly managed, leading to further complications such as pneumonia, acute respiratory distress syndrome, or respiratory arrest.
3. Cardiac complications: The patient's severe mitral and tricuspid regurgitation may lead to further cardiac complications, such as heart failure, cardiogenic shock, or arrhythmias.
4. Infection: The patient's sputum culture growing GNR and CXR showing evidence of LLL PNA suggest a potential infection, which may worsen if not properly treated.
5. Volume overload: The patient's fluid status is concerning, with a goal of I/O = -500cc today, and further fluid overload may lead to worsening respiratory failure, cardiac failure, or other complications.
6. Hypothyroidism: The patient's hypothyroidism may be contributing to her altered mental status and weakness, and further evaluation is needed to determine the underlying cause of her hypothyroidism.
7. Osteoporosis: The patient's osteoporosis may be contributing to her fragility and risk of further complications, such as fractures or osteoporotic crisis.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's neurological status and consider further evaluation, such as an MRI or EEG, to determine the underlying cause of her altered mental status and weakness.
2. Continue to manage the patient's respiratory failure with mechanical ventilation and wean as tolerated.
3. Continue to treat the patient's infection with antibiotics and monitor for signs of worsening infection.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's fluid status and adjust fluid management accordingly.
5. Consider further evaluation of the patient's cardiac status, including echocardiography, to determine the underlying cause of her cardiac disease.
6. Consider further evaluation of the patient's hypothyroidism, including thyroid function tests, to determine the underlying cause of her hypothyroidism.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's osteoporosis and consider further evaluation, such as a bone density scan, to determine the underlying cause of her osteoporosis.

 in case infection contributing

s: goal -500cc today; as concern for volume overload given

The patient is an 86-year-old female who was transferred to the ICU from another hospital for evaluation of respiratory arrest. She has a history of severe mitral regurgitation, severe tricuspid regurgitation, diastolic heart failure, and atrial fibrillation. She was intubated due to respiratory failure and has been receiving mechanical ventilation. She has also been experiencing hypotension, altered mental status, and significant bleeding from the right internal jugular (RIJ) removal site.

The patient's recent laboratory results show a decreased hemoglobin level, which is concerning for ongoing bleeding. Her respiratory status has improved, with a recent SpO2 of 100% and a respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute. Her blood pressure has also improved, with a current reading of 107/52 mmHg.

The patient's plan includes continuing antibiotic coverage for hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP), decreasing the dose of vancomycin, and monitoring her secretions. She is also scheduled for a chest physical therapy session after extubation.

Potential medical complications:

1. Ongoing bleeding: The patient's decreased hemoglobin level and ongoing bleeding from the RIJ removal site are concerning and require close monitoring.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is still compromised, and she may require continued mechanical ventilation.
3. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure has improved, but she may still be at risk for hypotension, especially if she experiences further bleeding or fluid shifts.
4. Altered mental status: The patient's altered mental status may be due to oversedation, but it is also possible that she may have an underlying infection or other medical condition that is contributing to her mental status changes.
5. Infection: The patient's sputum culture grew Gram-negative rods, which is concerning for a potential infection.
6. Valve disease: The patient has severe mitral regurgitation and tricuspid regurgitation, which may be contributing to her respiratory failure and dyspnea.
7. Hypothyroidism: The patient has a history of hypothyroidism, which may be contributing to her altered mental status and fatigue.
8. Crohn's disease: The patient has a history of Crohn's disease, which may be contributing to her altered mental status and fatigue.
9. Macular degeneration: The patient has a history of macular degeneration, which may be contributing to her altered mental status and fatigue.
10. Osteoporosis: The patient has a history of osteoporosis, which may be contributing to her altered mental status and fatigue.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management to address her ongoing bleeding, respiratory failure, and other medical complications.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is an 86-year-old female with a complex medical history, including severe mitral regurgitation, severe tricuspid regurgitation, diastolic heart failure, and atrial fibrillation. She was transferred to the ICU for evaluation of respiratory arrest.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory support: Invasive ventilation with CPAP/PSV mode, with a set Vt of 400 mL and a spontaneous Vt of 291 mL.
* Cardiovascular: The patient is in sinus rhythm, with a heart rate of 94 bpm. Her blood pressure is 107/52 mmHg, with a mean arterial pressure of 72 mmHg. Her cardiac output is decreased, with a cardiac index of 1.3 L/min/m2.
* Hemodynamic monitoring: The patient has a central venous pressure of 12 mmHg, a pulmonary artery pressure of 28/18 mmHg, and a pulmonary capillary wedge pressure of 18 mmHg.
* Fluid balance: The patient has received a total of 1,134 mL of IV fluids, with a net fluid balance of -1,151 mL.
* Renal function: The patient's creatinine level is 1.2 mg/dL, and her blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level is 26 mg/dL.
* Liver function: The patient's liver enzymes are elevated, with a alanine aminotransferase (ALT) level of 50 IU/L and an aspartate aminotransferase (AST) level of 41 IU/L.
* Electrolytes: The patient's sodium level is 140 mEq/L, her potassium level is 4.1 mEq/L, and her chloride level is 110 mEq/L.
* Infections: The patient has a respiratory culture growing a yeast, and her sputum culture is pending.
* Neurological: The patient's mental status is improved, but she is still intubated and requires respiratory support. She is able to follow commands and respond to verbal stimuli.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen if she is unable to be extubated, or if she develops a respiratory infection.
* Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiac output may continue to be decreased, leading to hypotension and decreased perfusion of vital organs.
* Infections: The patient's respiratory culture growing a yeast may indicate a fungal infection, which could spread to other parts of the body.
* Neurological complications: The patient's altered mental status may worsen if she develops a stroke or other neurological complications.
* Bleeding: The patient's recent bleeding from the removal site of her inferior vena cava filter may indicate a bleeding disorder or a clotting defect.
* Hypothyroidism: The patient's hypothyroidism may worsen if her thyroid hormone levels are not monitored and replaced as needed.
* Osteoporosis: The patient's osteoporosis may worsen if she is not receiving adequate treatment for her condition.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continue antibiotic coverage for HAP
* Monitor for signs of respiratory failure
* Monitor for signs of cardiac complications
* Monitor for signs of infections
* Monitor for signs of neurological complications
* Monitor for signs of bleeding
* Monitor for signs of hypothyroidism
* Monitor for signs of osteoporosis
* Consider valve replacement if the patient's symptoms worsen or if she develops a cardiac complication
* Continue to hold sedation as tolerated
* Consider extubation if the patient's mental status improves and she is able to protect her airway
* Continue to monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and adjust her medication as needed.

 86 yo female with severe mitral regurgitation, severe tricuspid
   regurgitation, diastolic heart failure, atrial fibrillation transferred
   from [**Location (un) **] for evaluation of respiratory arrest.
   .
   # RHYTHM:  The patient has recent history of rapid A fib s/p DC/CV and
   amiodarone/digoxin loading with subsequent bradycardia and junctional
   rhythm.  On arrival, patient was in A fib with RVR and hypotensive. In
   NSR since DC cardioversion.
   - Will hold AV nodal agents in the setting of recent junctional rhythm
   - Continue Amiodarone po 200mg daily
   - Continue heparin drip for anticoagulation (no coumadin, in case
   patient were to go for valvular surgery)
   .
   # PUMP:  The patient has diastolic heart failure on most recent echo,
   but preserved systolic function.  Valvular disorders including severe
   mitral regurgitation and tricuspid regurgitation may be contributing to
   patient's dyspnea/respiratory arrest.  If the patient is truly
   symptomatic from mitral regurgitation, she would meet criteria for
   valve replacement.  If her symptoms are secondary to other causes, she
   may still meet criteria given severe nature, presence of pulmonary
   hypertension and possible new recurrence of atrial fibrillation.
   However, in the setting of recent altered mental status, hypotension,
   and respiratory failure will likely not pursue aggressive intervention
   at this time.  Feel patient volume-overloaded at this point, s/p
   multiple fluid boluses for hypotension
   - goal I/O = -500cc today
   - Consult CT [**Doctor First Name **] for possible valve replacement once pt stable,
   extubated
   - Captopril 37.5mg po tid
   .
   # CORONARIES:  History of quadruple CABG in [**2169**], has not been
   reevaluated since.  No evidence of acute ischemia.  No ASA given
   history of PUD.
   - Continue plavix and pravastatin
   - Captopril 37.5mg tid
   .
   # Decreased Hct/Bleeding from R Neck:  Continued bleeding from prior R
   IJ site, had been bleeding since IJ was placed.  Likely damaged vein in
   neck during IJ placement.  Previously stable hct but this morning with
   decrease in hct from 27 -> 24.
   - [**Hospital1 **] Hct
   - US neck to evaluate for hematoma
   - Transfuse as needed for rapidly downtrending Hct or Hct<25 given h/o
   CAD
   .
   # Altered Mental Status:  Likely [**1-26**] oversedation, however cannot r/o
   stroke, infectious process.  TSH and metabolic profile WNL.  CT head
   negative for acute process. Significantly improved, alert and
   interactive currently.  Possible contribution from PNA which is
   currently being treated with Abx.
   - f/u UCx, U/A, sputum, blood culture
 in case infection contributing
   to a delirium picture
   - Full neuro exam today or tomorrow to assess for focal deficet, though
   unlikely
   - Assess pt
s baseline by discussion with family
   .
   # Respiratory Failure:  Per report from [**Location (un) **], the patient's
   respiratory failure had resolved, however on arrival patient unable to
   protect airway.  CXR on arrival was not especially concerning for
   volume overload or pneumonia, however sputum growing GNR, and CXR [**10-8**]
   shows evidence of LLL PNA. On pressure support previously, now
   extubated successfully.
   - Continue antibiotic coverage for HAP - Vanc/Zosyn (start date [**10-6**])
   x7d; today is last day ([**10-12**]).
   - Dosing Vanc by trough; last dose today given trough 16 this AM.
   - Nebs ordered prn
   - Chest PT s/p extubation
   - No Lasix for now; I
s & O
s goal  even today, given hypernatremia and
   lower BP.  Will reassess volume status daily and ensure tight control
   on afterload/SBP to prevent flash pulmonary edema given severe MR.
   .
   # Hypotension:  Likely secondary to A fib with RVR with component of
   infectious process/sepsis.  Cultures negative to date on Vanc/Zosyn,
   last day of abx today [**10-12**].  Questionable fluid status given
   hypernatremia and lack of pedal edema, but rales on exam (may be [**1-26**]
   atelectasis).  BP improved in sinus [**Date range (1) 8797**].  Blood pressures
   improved this morning in 90
   .
   # Cool LUE:  Dopplers of LUE showed normal flow, warmth improved with
   heating pad and decreased discoloration.
   .
   # Hypothyroidism: TSH WNL, continue levothyroxine at home doses.
   .
   # Crohn's Disease:  No acute issues, continue to monitor.
   .
   # Macular Degeneration:  Continue brimonidine eye drops and
   PreserVision vitamin supplementation.
   .
   # History of CVA:  Affected her right eye and is s/p left sided CEA.
   Continue plavix and pravastatin.  No aspirin secondary to PUD.
   .
   # PUD:  Continue home PPI
   .
   # Osteoporosis:  Continue actonel weekly
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: Cardiac diet.
   Replete lytes PRN.

   hyperglycemic (mostly 80s, 90s, 100s), so no treatment plan instituted
   thus far.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is an 86-year-old female with a complex medical history, including severe mitral regurgitation, severe tricuspid regurgitation, diastolic heart failure, atrial fibrillation, and a history of quadruple CABG. The patient was transferred from another location for evaluation of respiratory arrest.

The patient's recent events include:

* Extubation and subsequent development of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, leading to hypotension
* Bleeding from the right neck site, likely due to damage to the vein during insertion of the internal jugular catheter
* Altered mental status, which has improved with treatment and is now considered likely to be related to oversedation
* Respiratory failure, which resolved with pressure support and has now been successfully extubated
* Hypotension, which is likely secondary to atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response and possibly an infectious process
* Rales on exam, which may be related to atelectasis

The patient is currently receiving treatment for:

* Atrial fibrillation with amiodarone and heparin
* Bleeding from the right neck site, with plans for transfusion as needed and US neck evaluation
* Respiratory failure, with plans for continued antibiotic coverage and chest physical therapy
* Hypotension, with plans for continued monitoring and reassessment of volume status
* Altered mental status, with plans for further evaluation and management

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Further bleeding from the right neck site
* Development of acute kidney injury or acute respiratory distress syndrome
* Sepsis or septic shock
* Pneumonia or other infectious complications
* Flash pulmonary edema due to severe mitral regurgitation
* Stroke or transient ischemic attack due to atrial fibrillation

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Elevated troponin-T and creatine kinase, indicating possible myocardial injury
* Elevated lactate acid, indicating possible metabolic acidosis
* Elevated white blood cell count, indicating possible infection
* Elevated creatinine, indicating possible kidney dysfunction

The patient's imaging studies show:

* A CXR with evidence of left lower lobe pneumonia
* A Doppler study of the left upper extremity showing normal flow and warmth

The patient's medications include:

* Amiodarone for atrial fibrillation
* Heparin for anticoagulation
* Lasix for volume overload
* Captopril for heart failure
* Plavix and pravastatin for cardiac disease
* Levothyroxine for hypothyroidism
* Brimonidine eye drops and PreserVision vitamin supplementation for macular degeneration
* Plavix and pravastatin for history of CVA
* Home PPI for PUD
* Actonel weekly for osteoporosis

The patient's code status is full code, and her disposition is to the CCU.

 86 yo female with severe mitral regurgitation, severe tricuspid
   regurgitation, diastolic heart failure, atrial fibrillation transferred
   from [**Location (un) **] for evaluation of respiratory arrest.
   .
   # RHYTHM:  The patient has recent history of rapid A fib s/p DC/CV and
   amiodarone/digoxin loading with subsequent bradycardia and junctional
   rhythm.  On arrival, patient was in A fib with RVR and hypotensive. In
   NSR since DC cardioversion until [**10-11**] when patient went back into a
   fib with RVR, currently HR 90s-100s.
   - Continue Amiodarone drip
   - Continue Amiodarone po 200mg daily
   - Continue Heparin drip for anticoagulation (no coumadin, in case
   patient were to go for valvular surgery in the near future)
   - Will hold AV nodal agents in the setting of recent junctional rhythm
   at OSH
   .
   # Mitral Regurgitation/Tricuspid Regurgitation:  Mod-severe
   MR/mild-moderate TR on TTE in-house.  Will keep afterload reduced <120
   systolic to prevent flash pulmonary edema with MR.
   - Captopril 50mg tid for afterload reduction
   # PUMP:  The patient has diastolic heart failure on most recent echo,
   but preserved systolic function, TTE in-house showed EF 40%.  Valvular
   disorders including severe mitral regurgitation and tricuspid
   regurgitation may be contributing to patient's dyspnea/respiratory
   arrest.  If the patient is truly symptomatic from mitral regurgitation,
   she would meet criteria for valve replacement.  If her symptoms are
   secondary to other causes, she may still meet criteria given severe
   nature, presence of pulmonary hypertension and possible new recurrence
   of atrial fibrillation.  However, in the setting of recent altered
   mental status, hypotension, and recent extubation, will likely not
   pursue aggressive intervention at this time.  Feel patient euvolemic,
   will aim to keep even today.
   - goal I/O = even today
   - Captopril 50mg po tid
   - Pending resolution of acute issues, will consider consulting CT [**Doctor First Name **]
   for possible valve replacement in the future
   .
   # CORONARIES:  History of quadruple CABG in [**2169**], has not been
   reevaluated since.  No evidence of acute ischemia.  No ASA given
   history of PUD.
   - Continue plavix and pravastatin and captopril
   .
   # Decreased Hct/Bleeding from R Neck:  Continued bleeding from prior R
   IJ site, had been bleeding since IJ was placed.  Likely damaged vein in
   neck during IJ placement.  Previously stable hct but this morning with
   decrease in hct from 27 -> 24.
   - [**Hospital1 **] Hct
   - US neck to evaluate for hematoma
   - Transfuse as needed for rapidly downtrending Hct or Hct<25 given h/o
   CAD
   .
   # Altered Mental Status:  Likely [**1-26**] oversedation, however cannot r/o
   stroke, infectious process.  TSH and metabolic profile WNL.  CT head
   negative for acute process. Significantly improved, alert and
   interactive currently.  Possible contribution from PNA which is
   currently being treated with Abx.
   - f/u UCx, U/A, sputum, blood culture
 in case infection contributing
   to a delirium picture
   - Full neuro exam today or tomorrow to assess for focal deficet, though
   unlikely
   - Assess pt
s baseline by discussion with family
   .
   # Respiratory Failure:  Per report from [**Location (un) **], the patient's
   respiratory failure had resolved, however on arrival patient unable to
   protect airway.  CXR on arrival was not especially concerning for
   volume overload or pneumonia, however sputum growing GNR, and CXR [**10-8**]
   shows evidence of LLL PNA. On pressure support previously, now
   extubated successfully.
   - Continue antibiotic coverage for HAP - Vanc/Zosyn (start date [**10-6**])
   x7d; today is last day ([**10-12**]).
   - Dosing Vanc by trough; last dose today given trough 16 this AM.
   - Nebs ordered prn
   - Chest PT s/p extubation
   - No Lasix for now; I
s & O

   on afterload/SBP to prevent flash pulmonary edema given severe MR.
   .
   # Hypotension:  Likely secondary to A fib with RVR with component of
